thread.title: The five best ways to experience Havana
thread.title_full: The five best ways to experience Havana

title: The five best ways to experience Havana
text:
CNN Leadership
The five best ways to experience Havana Updated 1243 GMT (1943 HKT) September 25, 2015 10 photos: 'Parts Unknown': Cuba The United States and Cuba this year reestablished diplomatic relations that ended in 1961. Click through the gallery to explore the island as it starts to see historic changes. Hide Caption 1 of 10 10 photos: 'Parts Unknown': Cuba Fishing off the Malecón, a sea wall, in Havana. People exercise, make out or just gaze at the beautiful blue sea for hours. Hide Caption 10 photos: 'Parts Unknown': Cuba Looking north toward the ocean in Old Havana. Hide Caption 10 photos: 'Parts Unknown': Cuba A pedicab driver waits for a client in Havana's old town. Hide Caption 10 photos: 'Parts Unknown': Cuba The sun sets over Havana. Hide Caption 10 photos: 'Parts Unknown': Cuba An old Chevrolet passes a movie theater. Tickets cost only pennies for Cubans. Hide Caption 6 of 10 10 photos: 'Parts Unknown': Cuba Anthony Bourdain recently explored the nation on the brink of historic change. "Anthony Bourdain: Parts Unknown" in Cuba premieres Sunday, September 27, at 9 p.m. ET/PT on CNN. Hide Caption 7 of 10 10 photos: 'Parts Unknown': Cuba Havana locals dress up for a night of music and dancing. Some people like their venues big and loud. Others prefer places better known for the people-watching than the music. Hide Caption 8 of 10 10 photos: 'Parts Unknown': Cuba Bourdain meets legendary singer and performer Juana Bacallao, who once was a headliner at the storied Tropicana nightclub in the 1940s and 1950s. Bacallao still performs every Friday night at popular jazz club El Gato Tuerto. Hide Caption 9 of 10 10 photos: 'Parts Unknown': Cuba Children relax on a bench at Siboney Beach near Santiago de Cuba, the second largest city in Cuba and on the opposite end of the island from Havana. It has a totally different vibe. Hide Caption
